The dust kicked up from Russell's boots as he walked down the main street of Saskatoon, his spurs jingling with each step against the wooden boardwalk. The morning sun cast long shadows between the buildings, and somewhere in the distance a church bell was chiming eight o'clock. He adjusted his worn leather hat and squinted toward the schoolhouse at the end of the street, where smoke was already curling from the chimney.

Russell had never much cared for book learning, but at twenty-three he found himself drawn to that little red building every morning like a moth to flame. It wasn't the arithmetic or the reading that pulled him there—it was her. Miss Catherine Whitmore had arrived in town three months ago from back east, with her proper diction and her soft brown hair always pinned up neat as you please. She had a way of looking at a man that made him feel like maybe he was worth something more than just breaking horses and mending fences.

The other cowboys ribbed him mercilessly about his sudden interest in education. "Russell's gone soft," they'd say, laughing over their whiskey at the saloon. "Next thing you know, he'll be trading his six-shooter for a pencil." But Russell didn't much care what they thought. Every morning he'd wash his face extra careful, comb his hair back with water from the well, and make his way to that schoolhouse.

He pushed open the heavy wooden door and was greeted by the familiar smell of chalk dust and ink. The children were already seated at their desks, ranging in age from little Emma Peterson who couldn't have been more than six, to big Tom Hartwell who was pushing fifteen and looked like he'd rather be anywhere else on earth.

"Good morning, Russell," Miss Whitmore said without looking up from the blackboard where she was writing out the day's lesson in her neat, precise handwriting. Her voice had a musical quality that seemed to make even the simplest words sound important.

"Morning, Miss Whitmore," Russell replied, hanging his hat on the peg by the door. He took his usual seat in the back corner, his long legs folding awkwardly under the small desk that had clearly been built for someone considerably shorter.

The morning lesson was about geography, and Miss Whitmore spoke about places Russell had only heard mentioned in passing—cities like Boston and New York, oceans that stretched farther than a man could ride in a lifetime. She moved around the room with an easy grace, her dark blue dress rustling softly as she walked between the desks, checking the children's work.

"The Atlantic Ocean," she was saying, pointing to a large map that hung on the wall, "covers more than forty-one million square miles. Ships cross it regularly now, carrying passengers and cargo between America and Europe." Her finger traced the blue expanse, and Russell found himself wondering what it would be like to see something so vast, so endless.

During the noon break, while the children ran outside to play, Russell lingered behind. This had become their routine—a few precious minutes alone together while she tidied up her desk and prepared for the afternoon lessons.

"You're making good progress with your reading," she said, not looking at him directly but shuffling through a stack of papers. There was something different about her today, a kind of restlessness in the way she moved.

"I got a good teacher," Russell said, and was rewarded with the faintest smile.

"Russell, I..." she began, then stopped herself. She set down the papers and finally looked at him, her green eyes serious. "There's something I need to tell you."

The way she said it made something cold settle in Russell's stomach. He'd heard that tone before—it was the same way Doc Miller had sounded when he'd told Russell's pa that his ma wasn't going to get better from the fever.

"I've received a letter," Miss Whitmore continued. "From my uncle in Halifax. He runs a shipping company there, and he's offered me a position. A chance to see the world, to travel on his ships as they trade with ports across the ocean."

Russell felt like he'd been kicked by a mustang. "When?" was all he managed to say.

"The stage leaves for the railway station tomorrow morning. I'll take the train east to Halifax, and then..." She gestured toward the map on the wall. "Then wherever the ships take me."

The afternoon lessons passed in a blur. Russell heard Miss Whitmore's voice explaining mathematics problems and grammar rules, but the words seemed to come from very far away. He watched the way the afternoon sunlight fell across her face, tried to memorize the sound of her laugh when little Emma gave a particularly amusing answer to a question about animals.

When the school day ended and the children had all trooped home, Russell remained in his seat. Miss Whitmore was packing her few personal belongings into a small traveling case—a few books, some letters tied with ribbon, a daguerreotype of what looked like her parents.

"Catherine," he said, using her first name for the first time. She looked up, startled by the intimacy of it. "Don't go."

She was quiet for a long moment, her hands stilled on the clasp of her traveling case. "Russell, you know I can't stay. There's nothing for me here. This was always meant to be temporary."

"There could be something," he said, standing up and taking a step toward her. "There could be me."

The words hung between them in the dusty air of the schoolroom. Outside, they could hear the sounds of the town settling into evening—horses being led to the stable, the general store owner sweeping his front steps, somebody practicing fiddle music.

"I care about you," she said finally. "More than I should, perhaps. But Russell, I've spent my whole life in small towns like this one. I want to see what else is out there. I want to stand on the deck of a ship and watch the sunrise over an ocean. I want to visit places I've only read about in books."

Russell understood wanderlust—he'd felt it himself plenty of times, staring out at the endless prairie and wondering what lay beyond the horizon. But now, looking at her, all he wanted was for the horizon to shrink down to the size of this room, this moment, this woman with the serious green eyes and the dreams too big for Saskatoon.

"I could come with you," Russell said, the words tumbling out before he'd fully formed the thought. "I mean, I know it sounds crazy, but I could learn about ships and trading. I'm good with my hands, good with horses—maybe I could be good with other things too."

Catherine's expression softened, and for a moment he thought he saw something like hope flicker in her eyes. But then she shook her head, and he watched that brief light fade away like the last ember of a dying fire. "Russell, you belong here. This land, these wide open spaces—it's part of who you are. I've watched you when you talk about your ranch, about the horses you're training. Your whole face changes. You light up like a man talking about his first love."

"But you—" he started to say, then stopped himself. The truth was sitting there between them, too honest and too frightening to speak aloud. That maybe she had become his first love, or at least the first love that mattered in a way that made everything else seem small and distant.

Catherine moved closer to him, close enough that he could smell the lavender soap she used, could see the tiny freckles across the bridge of her nose that she tried to hide with powder. "And you're part of this place, Russell. You're woven into it like grass roots in prairie soil. If you came with me, you'd spend every day missing this sky, this freedom. You'd grow to resent the ocean because it's not the grassland, and you'd grow to resent me for taking you away from it."

Russell wanted to argue with her, wanted to tell her that she was wrong, that love could overcome anything. But even as the protest formed in his mind, he knew she was right. He thought about the few times he'd traveled to bigger cities for cattle sales, how the tall buildings had made him feel trapped and anxious, how he'd counted the days until he could return to the open range where a man could see for miles in every direction.

The silence stretched between them, filled with all the things they couldn't say, all the futures that would never unfold. Finally, Catherine reached into her traveling case and pulled out a slim volume bound in green leather. "I want you to have this," she said, pressing it into his hands. "It's a collection of poems about travel, about distant places. Maybe someday when you read it, you'll think of me standing on a ship's deck somewhere, watching the sun set over waters you've never seen."

Russell looked down at the book, running his thumb over the smooth leather cover. "What am I supposed to do tomorrow morning when I walk down that street and see the schoolhouse empty?"

"You're supposed to keep learning," she said. "Maybe not from books, but from everything around you. You're supposed to train your horses and work your land and find someone who loves this place the way you do." Her voice caught slightly on the last words, and Russell realized this conversation was costing her as much as it was costing him.

Outside, the church bell chimed six o'clock, and the sound seemed to break the spell that had held them suspended in this moment of possibility and loss. Catherine closed her traveling case with a decisive snap and smoothed down her skirt. "I should go. Mrs. Henderson is expecting me for supper, and I still have packing to finish."

Russell nodded, though everything in him wanted to protest, wanted to find some argument that would make her change her mind. Instead, he picked up his hat from the peg and settled it on his head, the familiar weight of it a small comfort. "I'll walk you to Mrs. Henderson's," he said.

They stepped out into the evening air together, and Russell was struck by how normal everything looked. The same dusty street, the same weathered buildings, the same endless sky stretching out in all directions. It seemed impossible that the world could look exactly the same when everything had just changed so completely.

They walked slowly down the main street, their footsteps creating a quiet rhythm on the wooden boardwalk. The evening air carried the familiar scents of Saskatoon—dust and hay, wood smoke from dinner fires, the faint smell of leather from the saddle maker's shop. Russell found himself trying to memorize everything about this moment, the way the dying light caught the golden threads in Catherine's brown hair, the soft rustle of her skirts as she walked beside him, the careful distance she maintained between them that somehow felt more intimate than if they had been touching.

Other townspeople nodded to them as they passed—Mrs. Patterson hanging laundry behind the general store, old Pete Miller sitting on his porch whittling, the Jameson boys driving their father's cattle back from the day's grazing. To everyone else, it must have looked like any ordinary evening, the schoolteacher and the young cowboy walking together in the comfortable quiet of a prairie sunset. None of them could know that this simple walk contained all the weight of goodbye, all the sharp edges of a future that would unfold differently than either Russell or Catherine had begun, perhaps foolishly, to imagine.

Mrs. Henderson's boarding house sat at the end of Oak Street, a tidy white building with green shutters and a front porch lined with flower boxes. Catherine had been staying there since her arrival in town, renting the small upstairs room that looked out over the church and the cemetery beyond. Russell had passed by that window countless times in the past three months, sometimes catching a glimpse of lamplight in the evening and wondering what she was doing up there—reading, perhaps, or writing letters to family back east, or simply looking out at this foreign landscape and trying to decide what she thought of it all.

They paused at the bottom of the porch steps, and Russell realized this was where they would part ways. Tomorrow morning he would see her climb aboard the eastbound stage with her traveling case and her dreams of oceans and distant shores, but this quiet moment in the gathering dusk was their real goodbye. Everything else would be public, observed by the curious eyes of townspeople who would no doubt have plenty to say about the schoolteacher's sudden departure and the cowboy who had been fool enough to think he could learn to love books and proper grammar.

"Russell," Catherine said, and her voice was softer now, less certain than it had been in the schoolroom. "I need you to know that these past months... they've meant something to me. More than I expected when I first came here." She looked down at her hands, clasped tightly in front of her. "I came to Saskatoon thinking it would be just another temporary stop, another small town where I could teach for a while and save money for my real adventures. I never thought I would meet someone who would make me question whether those adventures were what I really wanted."

The confession hung between them like something fragile and precious, and Russell felt his heart do something complicated in his chest. Part of him wanted to seize on her words, to use them as ammunition in an argument for her to stay. But a larger part of him recognized the gift she was giving him—the knowledge that his feelings hadn't been entirely one-sided, that whatever had grown between them in that little red schoolhouse had been real and mutual, even if it wasn't strong enough to overcome the pull of her larger dreams.

"I know," he said simply, and was surprised by how steady his voice sounded. "I felt it too. Still do." He shifted the book of poems from one hand to the other, using the movement to buy himself a moment to find the right words. "But feeling something doesn't always mean acting on it, does it? Sometimes the kindest thing you can do for someone is let them go where they need to go."

Catherine looked up at him then, and in the fading light he could see something that might have been tears gathering in her green eyes. "When did you become so wise?" she asked, and there was something almost like wonder in her voice.

"Must have been all that book learning," Russell said, managing a small smile. "Turns out education does strange things to a man's perspective." It was a weak attempt at humor, but it achieved what he'd hoped—Catherine smiled back, a real smile that reached her eyes and reminded him of all the small moments of connection they had shared over the past months. The way she had looked when he successfully read his first complete page without stumbling over the words. The afternoon she had stayed late to help him understand a particularly difficult mathematics concept, their heads bent close together over the slate board. The morning he had brought her wildflowers from the prairie and watched her face light up with genuine delight.

The front door of the boarding house opened, and Mrs. Henderson appeared, wiping her hands on her apron. She was a stout, practical woman in her fifties who had been widowed young and had made her living taking in boarders and occasional travelers. She had a kind heart beneath her no-nonsense exterior, and Russell had always suspected she was fonder of Catherine than she let on.

"There you are, dear," Mrs. Henderson said, addressing Catherine. "Supper's been ready this past quarter hour, and it won't improve with waiting." Her eyes moved to Russell, taking in the book in his hands and the careful way he and Catherine were standing apart from each other. Mrs. Henderson had lived long enough to recognize the signs of a difficult parting, and her expression softened slightly. "Evening, Russell. I suppose you've heard about our Miss Whitmore's great adventure."

"Yes ma'am," Russell replied, touching the brim of his hat politely. "Sounds like quite an opportunity." He was proud of how normal he sounded, how successfully he was hiding the fact that his chest felt like it was being squeezed by invisible hands.

"Indeed it is," Mrs. Henderson agreed, though Russell thought he detected a note of sadness in her voice as well. "We'll all miss her, that's certain. The children especially—they've grown quite attached to their teacher." She held the door open wider. "Catherine, dear, you'd better come in and eat something. Tomorrow will be a long day of travel, and you'll need your strength."

Catherine nodded and gathered her skirts to climb the porch steps, but she paused on the second step and turned back to Russell. For a moment it seemed like she might say something more, might offer some final words that would somehow make this parting easier or more complete. Instead, she simply looked at him, and Russell found himself memorizing the exact shade of green in her eyes, the way the evening light fell across her face, the small beauty mark just below her left ear that he had noticed weeks ago and thought about far more often than was probably appropriate.

"Goodbye, Russell," she said finally, and the simple words carried the weight of all the conversations they would never have, all the mornings he would never again watch her write lessons on the blackboard, all the possibilities that would remain forever unexplored.

"Goodbye, Catherine," he replied, and then she was disappearing through Mrs. Henderson's front door, leaving him standing alone on the empty street with a book of poetry and the beginning of an ache that he suspected would take a very long time to fade.

**Chapter 2**

Russell woke before dawn the next morning, pulled from restless sleep by the sound of the eastbound stage rumbling into town. He had spent the night tossing and turning in his narrow bunk at the ranch, Catherine's book of poetry lying unopened on the small table beside his bed. Every time he had started to drift off, his mind would conjure up images of her packing her few belongings by lamplight, or sitting by her window looking out at the prairie one last time, and sleep would slip away from him like water through cupped hands.

The other ranch hands were still snoring in their bunks as Russell pulled on his boots and stepped outside into the pre-dawn darkness. The air was crisp and clean, carrying the promise of another hot day once the sun climbed higher in the sky. In the distance, he could see the lights of Saskatoon flickering like fallen stars, and somewhere among those lights, Catherine was probably awake too, making her final preparations for the journey that would take her away from this place forever.

Russell saddled his horse, a sturdy bay mare named Clara who had been his companion for the past three years, and rode slowly toward town. He told himself he was going in early to pick up supplies at the general store, maybe grab breakfast at the hotel dining room before starting the day's work. But even as he constructed these reasonable explanations for his early morning ride, he knew the truth—he needed to see the stage leave. He needed to witness the moment when Catherine disappeared from his life, to make it real and final in a way that their conversation yesterday evening had not quite accomplished.

The main street of Saskatoon was already showing signs of activity despite the early hour. The stage driver was checking the harnesses on his team of six horses, their breath visible in small puffs of vapor in the cool air. Several passengers were milling about near the stage office, their traveling cases and carpet bags stacked nearby like small monuments to departure and change. Russell recognized a few faces—traveling salesmen who made regular circuits through the territories, a well-dressed couple who looked like they might be heading back east after visiting relatives, an elderly man with a medical bag who was probably the new doctor everyone had been talking about for weeks.

Russell dismounted and tied Clara to the hitching post outside Peterson's General Store, positioning himself where he could observe the stage preparations without being too obvious about it. The store wouldn't open for another hour, but old Peterson lived above his shop and would probably not mind if Russell waited on the front porch. The wooden steps creaked familiarly under his boots as he settled himself on the bench that Peterson kept outside for customers who wanted to sit and chat while their wives shopped for dry goods and household necessities.

From this vantage point, Russell could see the boarding house clearly, and as the sky began to lighten from black to deep purple, he spotted movement in the upstairs window that he knew belonged to Catherine's room. A lamp flickered to life, casting a warm yellow glow against the glass, and Russell found himself imagining her final preparations—folding her few dresses carefully into her traveling case, pinning her hair up in the neat style she always wore, perhaps taking one last look around the small room that had been her home for these past three months.

The town continued to wake up around him as he waited. The blacksmith arrived to open his shop, nodding to Russell with the easy familiarity of men who had known each other for years but had never found much occasion for conversation beyond the weather and the health of their respective horses. The hotel cook stepped outside to shake crumbs from her apron, releasing the first promising smells of bacon and fresh biscuits into the morning air. A few early risers emerged from their houses to tend to chickens or milk cows, beginning the daily routines that would continue unchanged long after Catherine had disappeared over the horizon.

Russell pulled Catherine's book from his jacket pocket and opened it randomly, trying to distract himself from the growing knot of anticipation in his stomach. The page he had chosen contained a poem about sailing ships and foreign ports, and he wondered if Catherine had marked this particular poem for some reason, or if fate was simply determined to twist the knife a little deeper. The words swam before his eyes as he tried to focus on them, but his attention kept drifting back to the boarding house window and the preparations happening all around the stage.

"Bit early for poetry reading, isn't it?" The voice startled Russell, and he looked up to see Doc Peterson emerging from the general store, a steaming cup of coffee in his hands and an expression of mild curiosity on his weathered face. Peterson was one of the few people in town who had treated Russell's sudden interest in education as something admirable rather than amusing, perhaps because the storekeeper had been one of the few educated men in Saskatoon before Catherine's arrival.

"Couldn't sleep," Russell replied, closing the book and slipping it back into his pocket. "Figured I might as well come to town early and get a start on the day." It was not quite a lie, but it was not quite the truth either, and Russell suspected that Peterson was shrewd enough to read between the lines.

Peterson settled himself on the bench beside Russell, blowing on his coffee to cool it. "That's the eastbound stage getting ready to leave," he observed, as if Russell might not have noticed the large vehicle and team of horses situated directly in front of them. "Taking some folks away from us today, I hear. Including our schoolteacher." There was something careful about the way Peterson said this, as if he was testing Russell's reaction.

"So I understand," Russell said, keeping his voice as neutral as possible. "Sounds like she's got an opportunity back east. Good for her, I suppose." The words tasted like sawdust in his mouth, but he managed to deliver them with something approaching conviction.

Peterson sipped his coffee thoughtfully, his sharp eyes taking in Russell's tense posture and the careful way he was avoiding looking directly at the boarding house. "Miss Whitmore was a fine teacher," he said after a moment. "My granddaughter Emma learned more in these past three months than she had in the previous year with old Mr. Hartwell. It's a shame we couldn't convince her to make her situation here more permanent." There was a subtle emphasis on the word 'we' that made Russell wonder exactly what Peterson suspected about his feelings for Catherine.

Before Russell could formulate a response, the boarding house door opened and Catherine emerged, carrying her traveling case and wearing a dark green dress that Russell had seen only once before, on her first day in town. Mrs. Henderson followed close behind, carrying what appeared to be a wrapped package of food for the journey and wearing the expression of a woman trying very hard not to cry in public. The two women made their way slowly down Oak Street toward the stage, their quiet conversation too distant for Russell to overhear.

Russell felt his chest tighten as Catherine approached the main street, her steps measured and deliberate. She had pinned her hair back more severely than usual, and the effect made her look older, more formal, like she was already becoming the sophisticated traveler she intended to be rather than the small-town schoolteacher she was leaving behind. When she reached the stage, the driver hurried forward to take her traveling case, and Russell watched as she exchanged polite pleasantries with the other passengers, her eastern education evident in the graceful way she navigated these social interactions.

"Young man," Peterson said quietly, "I've lived in this town for thirty-seven years, and I've seen a lot of people come and go. Some departures are just business, and some are personal. If this is personal, and if there are things that need saying, you've got about ten minutes before that stage rolls out of here and takes your opportunity with it." Peterson stood up, brushing imaginary dust from his pants. "Of course, sometimes the kindest thing you can do is let someone go without making it harder than it already is. That's a judgment call only you can make." With that cryptic advice, he disappeared back into his store, leaving Russell alone with his churning thoughts and the increasingly urgent sounds of departure preparation.

Russell stood up abruptly, his decision made before his conscious mind had fully processed it. He would not chase after Catherine or make some dramatic declaration that would only burden her with guilt and second thoughts. But he could not let her leave without at least saying goodbye properly, without letting her know that someone in this small prairie town would remember her kindly and wish her well on whatever adventures awaited her beyond the horizon. He walked across the street toward the stage, his boot heels ringing against the wooden boardwalk with each measured step.

Catherine was adjusting the clasp on her traveling case when she noticed Russell approaching. For just a moment, her composed expression flickered, revealing something that might have been relief or regret before she smoothed her features back into the polite mask she had been wearing since emerging from the boarding house. She straightened her shoulders and turned to face him, her hands clasped carefully in front of her in a gesture that Russell had come to recognize as her way of maintaining control when she was feeling uncertain.

"Russell," she said, her voice carrying that same musical quality that had first caught his attention months ago, though now it seemed more carefully modulated, as if she was consciously trying to strike the right tone between warmth and propriety. "I wondered if I might see you this morning." The admission surprised him, and he found himself searching her face for clues about what she might be feeling beneath her carefully maintained composure.

"Couldn't let you leave without wishing you a safe journey," Russell replied, stopping a respectful distance away from her. He was acutely aware of the other passengers nearby, the stage driver checking his pocket watch, Mrs. Henderson hovering protectively close to Catherine's elbow. This was not the place for intimate conversations or emotional farewells, and perhaps that was for the best. Sometimes the most important things were said in the spaces between words, in the way two people looked at each other when they both knew that time was running out.

The morning sun was climbing higher now, painting the dusty street in shades of gold and amber that reminded Russell of autumn wheat fields ready for harvest. Catherine's traveling dress absorbed the light, making her seem simultaneously more substantial and more ethereal, as if she was already beginning the transformation from the woman he had known to the adventurous traveler she intended to become. The thought struck him that he was witnessing not just her departure but her metamorphosis, and while the loss of it made his chest ache, there was something beautiful about watching someone step deliberately toward their dreams.

"All aboard for the eastbound express!" the stage driver called out, his voice cutting through the morning air with practiced authority. "Next stops Winnipeg, then connecting service to Toronto and points east!" The announcement galvanized the other passengers into motion, and Russell watched as the well-dressed couple hurried to claim their seats, the elderly doctor carefully climbed the steps with his medical bag clutched protectively to his chest, and one of the traveling salesmen made a last-minute dash to the hotel dining room for coffee to sustain him through the first leg of the journey.

Catherine glanced toward the stage, then back at Russell, and he could see the conflict playing out behind her green eyes. Part of her was already gone, he realized, already standing on the deck of some ship watching foreign coastlines slide past, already walking through streets in cities whose names he could barely pronounce. But part of her was still here in this dusty prairie town, still the woman who had spent patient hours teaching him to read poetry and solve arithmetic problems, still the person who had made him believe that he might be capable of becoming something more than just another cowboy breaking horses and mending fences.

"I have something for you," Catherine said suddenly, reaching into the small handbag she carried. She pulled out what appeared to be a letter, sealed with wax and addressed in her neat handwriting. "Don't read it now," she added quickly, pressing the envelope into his hands. "Wait until... well, wait until later. When you have time to think about it properly." Her fingers brushed against his as she transferred the letter, and Russell felt a jolt of electricity at the brief contact, a reminder of all the casual touches that might have developed into something deeper if circumstances had been different.

Russell tucked the letter into his jacket pocket, next to the book of poetry she had given him the evening before. He was accumulating tokens of her presence, he realized, small physical reminders that would have to sustain him through whatever came after this morning. The thought of reading her letter filled him with both anticipation and dread—what could she have written that she had not been able to say aloud? What final thoughts or confessions had she committed to paper in the privacy of her boarding house room, by lamplight, in the quiet hours before departure?

"Miss Whitmore, we really must be getting along now," the stage driver called, consulting his pocket watch with the air of a man who had learned that schedules were sacred things that must not be trifled with. "We've got a tight connection to make in Winnipeg, and the railway won't wait for stragglers." His tone was not unkind, but it carried the weight of practical necessity, the reminder that the larger world operated according to timetables and distant obligations that cared nothing for small-town farewells.

Catherine nodded and turned toward the stage, but then she paused and looked back at Russell one more time. In that moment, with the morning light falling across her face and her hand resting on the stage door, she looked younger somehow, more vulnerable, and Russell caught a glimpse of the uncertainty she had been working so hard to hide. "Take care of yourself, Russell," she said, and her voice was softer now, more personal. "Keep reading. Keep learning. Don't let anyone convince you that wanting to improve yourself is something to be ashamed of."

The advice hit him harder than he had expected, perhaps because it revealed how well she had come to understand him during their months of morning lessons. She had seen through his rough exterior to the hunger underneath, the desire to be more than what circumstances had made him, and she had never once made him feel foolish for wanting to better himself. In a world where most people were quick to put others into categories and keep them there, Catherine had seen possibilities where others saw only limitations.

"I won't," Russell promised, and he meant it in a way that surprised him with its intensity. Whatever else happened, he would not let her faith in him be wasted. He would continue the education she had started, would find ways to grow and learn even without her patient guidance. It would be a way of honoring what had passed between them, of ensuring that their connection continued to matter even after she had disappeared beyond the horizon.

Mrs. Henderson stepped forward then, wrapping Catherine in a fierce embrace that spoke of genuine affection despite their relatively short acquaintance. "You write to me, you hear?" the older woman said, her voice thick with emotion she was no longer trying to hide. "I want to know about all these grand adventures you're going to have. The warmth in her voice made it clear that Catherine had found more than just lodging at the boarding house—she had found a friend, perhaps even a surrogate mother figure, and leaving her behind was costing something as well.

Catherine hugged Mrs. Henderson back, and Russell could see tears gathering in her eyes despite her efforts to maintain her composure. "I'll write," she promised. "And I'll never forget your kindness to a stranger who showed up on your doorstep with more dreams than sense." The exchange reminded Russell that he was not the only person Catherine was leaving behind, that her departure would create ripples of loss throughout the small community that had briefly been her home.

The stage driver cleared his throat meaningfully, and Catherine finally allowed him to help her up into the coach. The morning sun streaming through the window caught the golden threads in her brown hair, and for a moment she looked like something from one of the illustrations in the books she had shared with him—a romantic figure embarking on some grand literary adventure.

The other passengers were settling themselves as well, the traveling salesman consulting what appeared to be a thick ledger book, the elderly doctor organizing his medical supplies, the well-dressed couple speaking quietly to each other about connections and schedules. Each of them was carrying their own stories, their own reasons for being on this particular stage on this particular morning, but Russell found he could think of nothing beyond the woman by the window who had changed his understanding of what his life might become.

"Step back, folks!" the driver called as he climbed up to his seat and gathered the reins in his experienced hands. The team of horses shifted restlessly in their harnesses, eager to be moving after their morning rest. Mrs. Henderson moved back onto the boardwalk, dabbing at her eyes with her apron, while Russell remained standing in the street, his hat in his hands, looking up at Catherine's window.

She had been watching him, he realized, and when their eyes met through the glass, she raised her hand in a small wave that somehow managed to convey both farewell and promise. Russell nodded back, not trusting himself to attempt anything more elaborate, and then the driver was releasing the brake and calling to his horses, and the stage was lurching into motion with the familiar creaking of leather and wood that had provided the soundtrack to countless departures over the years.

Russell stood motionless as the stage rolled down the main street, gathering speed as it headed toward the edge of town and the open prairie beyond. He could see Catherine's face in the window, growing smaller and less distinct with each passing moment, until finally the stage crested the small hill at the eastern edge of Saskatoon and disappeared from view, leaving nothing behind but dust settling slowly in the morning air and the gradually fading sound of wheels and hoofbeats.

The street seemed strangely quiet after the stage's departure, as if the town itself needed a moment to adjust to this new absence. Mrs. Henderson was walking slowly back toward her boarding house, her shoulders sagging with the weight of goodbye. The other early risers who had paused to watch the stage's departure were returning to their morning routines, and already the extraordinary was becoming ordinary again, another departure in a long series of arrivals and departures that marked the rhythm of life in a prairie town.

Russell remained standing in the street for several more minutes, staring at the horizon where the stage had disappeared. The letter in his pocket felt warm against his chest, and he found himself wondering what Catherine had written during her final evening in Saskatoon, what words she had chosen to leave with him. Part of him wanted to tear open the envelope immediately, to devour whatever message she had left behind, but her instruction to wait seemed important somehow, a final test of patience and respect.

The sun was climbing higher now, and Russell knew that his absence from the ranch would soon be noticed and remarked upon. There were horses to exercise, fences to mend, a dozen mundane tasks that would help fill the space that Catherine's departure had left behind. But first, he walked slowly back to where Clara was tied outside Peterson's General Store, his mind still processing the finality of what had just occurred. As he untied Clara's reins and prepared to mount, Russell caught sight of the schoolhouse at the end of the street, its red paint bright in the morning sun but its windows dark and empty. Russell swung himself into the saddle and turned Clara toward home, but before leaving town, he allowed himself one last look at Mrs. Henderson's boarding house, at the upstairs window where Catherine had spent her final night in Saskatoon. By evening, Mrs. Henderson would probably have stripped the bed and swept the floors, preparing the space for whatever traveler might next need temporary shelter on their way to somewhere else.

The ride back to the ranch gave Russell time to think, and as Clara's steady gait carried them across the familiar landscape of rolling grassland and endless sky, he found himself considering Catherine's parting words about continuing his education. The local preacher had a small library, he remembered, and there was talk of starting a lending library in town once someone could be found to organize it. The book of poetry Catherine had given him was a start, but it need not be an ending. He could honor what had passed between them by refusing to let his mind go fallow, by continuing to grow into the man she had glimpsed beneath his rough exterior.

By the time Russell reached the ranch, the other hands were already about their morning tasks, and his late arrival drew some good-natured ribbing from the men who had been teasing him about his educational pursuits for months. But their jokes seemed gentler today, perhaps because something in his expression warned them that the situation had changed, that whatever had been happening between the cowboy and the schoolteacher had reached some kind of resolution.

Russell threw himself into the day's work with an intensity that surprised his colleagues, mucking stalls and repairing tack with the focused energy of a man trying to exhaust his body so thoroughly that his mind would have no choice but to rest. **Chapter 3**
